reviewText: This Christmas classic by Rankin & Bass puts Santa and Rudolph aside except for very brief appearances and focuses on events leading to the  birth of Christ.  Not to many specials even mention the nativity scene  anymore.  If you liked this Christmas Classic check out THE FIRST CHRISTMAS  by Rankin & Bass.
summary: A story with a sad beginning but a good ending!
Title: N/A

reviewText: It's So Awesome, And Adorable. The Movie Starts Off When Santa Claus And His Reindeer Flew Away. And Mrs. Claus And The Elves Wave Good-Bye To Santa Claus. Then A Donkey Named Speltoe Showed Us A Snowplow And A Toy Cart That He Pulled. And He Also Gave Us A Tour Of The Reindeer Barn Where He And The Other Reindeer Sleep At. He Showed Us, Dasher's Stall, Dancer's Stall, Prancer's Stall, Vixen's Stall, Comet's Stall Cupid's Stall, Donner's Stall, Blitzen's Stall, And Roudolph's Stall Too. Then He Showed Us The Christmas Tree. And Below The Christmas Tree We See The Manger With, The Virgin Mary And Joseph And Baby Jesus. And The Animals. Then Speltoe Told Us That The Donkey Was His Ancister Nester. Then Speltoe Told Us The Story About Him. And The Story About Nester Dates Back In The Roman Empire Times. Way Before Christ Was Born. In A Small Farm Where Nester Lived With His Mom And A Host Of Other Animals. Nester Was Always Tripping Over His Long Ears. And No-One Wanted Him To Play With Them. Then When The Owner And His Dog Came Into The Barn To Feed The Animals. The Owner Fed Nester's Mom. But Not Nester. Then On The Next Night. The Animals In The Barn Were Having A Party. And They Were Giving Eachother Presents. Then Nester's Mom Gave Nester A Pair Of Old Wool Socks. And The Cute Little Donkeys Were Starting To Like Nester. Then When The Party Was Over. All Of The Animals Went To Sleep. When Suddenly The Barn Door Burst Open. And There Were Three Roman Soldiars Appeared In The Barn Doorway. Then All Of The Animals Woked Up. Then The Owner Came And Asked The Leader Of The Three Roman Soldiars What Do They Want. Then The Leader Of The Three Roman Soldiars Told The Owner That The Emperor Wants Strong Young Donkeys And He Told The Owner To Show Them To Him. Then The Owner Led The Three Roman Soldiars To The Cute Little Donkeys. Then The Three Roman Soldiars Grabed Some Of The Young Donkeys. Then They Grabbed Nester Too. Then Nester's Mom Was Upset. Until They Found Nester's Long Ears. And They Decided Not To Take Him But They Took The Others Instead. Then The Owner Was Sad. Then The Three Roman Soldiars Took The Other Young Donkeys Away. Then The Owner Was Mad At Nester. Then He Threw Nester Outside. Then Nester Was Scared And All Alone. Until His Mom Came. She Had Got Away From The Owner And Ran Outside The Barn To Look For Her Son. Then She And Nester Went Somewhere. Then She Dug A Hole In The Snow. And Told Nester To Get In. Then Nester Went Into The Hole. And She Covered Her Son Up. Then The Next Morning Nester Was Sad Because His Mom Had Died. She Sacraficed Herself To Save Him. Now Nester Was Alone Again. So If You Want To Know What Happens To Nester Next. Then You Should Buy This Movie. It's A Great Christmas Present For Your Children.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is one Christmas tale that I really want to love - it has the charm of the Rankin & Bass stop-motion holiday classics, it features one of my favorite artists (Roger Miller) doing the narration & songs, and it is bold enough to venture into the religious meaning of Christmas.  But unfortunately this one just doesn't come together.First, at approximately 30 minutes it is too short and feels rushed.  The story doesn't have time to unfold with much drama and the climactic dilemma of the sandstorm is very anticlimactic.  My favorite Rankin & Bass Christmas shows, like Rudolph and Santa Claus is Comin' to Town, were designed as hour long broadcasts and the extra time to develop the characters and story pays off.  Second, the music is not very good - and again, I am a huge Roger Miller fan.  The signature song that is woven through the story is just an average ditty far less memorable than Burl Ives' songs from Rudolph, for example.  Finally, the odd mix of religious and secular ideas and characters is weird and might confuse children of families wanting to teach their kids about Jesus and His birth.  You've got Nestor the fictitious donkey, historical Roman soldiers, a fairy-like cherub (which we learn is not an angel - cherubs are creatures put there to help animals fulfill God's plans!?!), Joseph and Mary, etc.  All in all an odd mix for me.I watched Nestor with my 4 year old son and there was an obvious disinterest for him.  He normally dialogues with me a lot when he likes a show and gets into the story, but Nestor came and went with little response from him at all.  I really want to like Nestor, but this one just doesn't make the cut as a Christmas classic.  Check out Disney's little known animated Christmas tale "Small One" for a much more engaging and memorable tale about a special donkey!
summary: Not One of Rankin & Bass' Best
Title: N/A

reviewText: When Nestor, a donkey with unusually long ears, is born in a small stable near Bethlehem, he is mocked by everyone. And soon, him and his Mother are thrown out of the stable, into a terrible blizzard. Nestor's Mother, wanting to keep her child warm, covers him with her body, and, when Nestor awakes the next morning, he finds his beloved Mother dead. Frozen to death while trying to protect her baby. When the springtime comes, Nestor meets a young cherub, who helps to guide him on his path to save another, as his Mother saved him. And when two travelers choose Nestor for a trip to a manger near Bethlehem, Nestor knows that he can finally accomplish his mission in life.Out of ever holiday story, NESTOR THE LONG-EARED CHRISTMAS DONKEY, is, and always will be, one of the most touching, and heartwarming movies ever created. Rankin/Bass did a fantastic job with the animation and dialogue in this film. And Nestor is one of the sweetest, and kindest characters to ever appear in a holiday special. Rankin/Bass really made it so that you sympathize with Nestor throughout the entire movie. Which is a huge plus. A must-have holiday film for the entire family this year.Erika Sorocco
Title: N/A

reviewText: While not as well known as some Rankin & Bass stop motion animated films such as "A Year Without a Santa Claus", this film is not anything less than what you'd expect from Rankin & Bass.Absolutely  charming.Very sweet & touching tale of Nestor, a donkey with  extremely long ears.  He's ridiculed and made fun of, and his only source  of comfort and love is his mother, who loves him unconditionally.  Nestor  and his mother end up lost in the snow, and unfortunately, his mother dies  protecting Nestor from the elements, which no matter how old I get sends me  into a crying jag. (I don't mean to ruin it for anyone, I just thought I'd  give parents the heads up to prepare the little ones for it).But it's  true what does not kill you makes you stronger, and Nestor goes on to  divine greatness.  A touching and sweet holiday film indeed.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I watched this movie for the first time last night. It hurt my heart seeing how Nester was treated, thrown and tossed around like that by his ears with that horrible look on his face and then have his mother die out in the snow, dear gosh I had to get tissues.  However, the ending is wonderful, I just wish it had been longer to counteract the sorrowful beginning. Its a beautiful story, I enjoy these holiday classics that talk about the true meaning of Christmas

reviewText: This is a classic in its own right. I can't watch this Christmas special without tears coming to my eyes. Nestor, who is ridiculed by his friends because of his long ears, has to find the purpose why he was given those ears. Part of it includes his mother sacrificing herself so Nestor can live.In the end, he does find his way to Bethlehem, just in time to meet Mary and Joseph and bear her to the town. It starts out sad, but brings tears of joy in the end. A great Chrismas classic!
summary: Brings Tears to my eyes every time!
